A Fort Worth police officer shot and wounded a suicidal woman who was holding a knife late night after the officer “perceived a deadly threat,” the department said.  Police responded shortly after 11:30 p.m. to the 5900 block of Greenspoint Drive, near Boca Raton Boulevard and Oakland Hills Drive. A woman had called and said she was “bleeding out” and attempting suicide, the department said.  The first officer at the scene found the caller at her door, police said, and the woman picked up a knife.  “As the interaction continued, the officer perceived a deadly threat from the subject and discharged their firearm, striking the subject,” the department said in a news release.  Breaking News Get the latest breaking news from North Texas and beyond. Email Address By signing up you agree to our Terms of Service and Privacy Policy SUBMIT  The statement did not describe the threat. Fort Worth police did not say how much time elapsed between the officer being on scene and shooting the woman, how many times the woman was shot or describe whether any attempts were made to de-escalate the situation.  The woman, who was not identified by police, was taken to a hospital and was stable. It was unclear whether she would face any charges.  The officer was not injured.  The department’s major-case and internal-affairs units will investigate the shooting.

Call, text or chat 988 any time, any place around-the-clock 24/7.  988 has been officially designated as the quick and easy 3-digit calling code that will be answered by trained Lifeline Specialist at the National Suicide and Crisis Lifeline for thoughts of suicide, alcohol or drug crisis, disaster survivors, LGBTQIA+, or any forms of mental health or neurodivergence concerns.  Statistical facts have shown that almost 98% of people who call, chat or text 988 get the crisis support they need and do not require additional services at that moment. Each Lifeline Specialists is trained to help reduce the intensity of a situation for the individual seeking help, and connect that person to additional local resources, as needed, to support their health and well-being. The single most important thing you can do is to know that 988 begins with knowledge. Ultimately, knowing when you are overwhelmed and need someone to communicate with.  Numerous studies have proven the positive effects associated with reduced stress and improved immunity. According to a 2020 research study in the Mental Health and Psychology Journal, science has proven some simple hacks to promote happiness.  Smile everyday  Tip: “…say cheese”  Smiling is one of the simplest, yet most powerful things you can do to brighten your day and it’s also contagious. When you smile, the muscles in your face stimulate the muscles in the faces of the people around you, ultimately causing them to smile too.  Treat yourself like a friend  Tip: Schedule “…me time!”  You’re always there for your family and friends, but now it’s time to take care of yourself. Eating healthy, getting enough sleep, and taking breaks when you need them are all essential for feeling your best. When you take care of yourself, you’re more likely to feel happy and healthy.  Be grateful  Tip: Start every morning acknowledging at least one thing your grateful for or would you rather write it in a gratitude journal  Being grateful for what you have is a great way to boost your mood and feel happier. When you take the time to appreciate the good in your life, you’re more likely to feel positive and hopeful. This is a great way to boost your mood and feel happiness.  Get physical  Tip: Don’t just sit, get your 30-minute fix  Any form of movement is good for your mental health. Activity and exercise has been shown to lower stress levels, improve mood, and boost self-esteem.  Live in the present moment  Tip: Try mindfulness meditation or prayer  Acknowledge and challenge negative thoughts. It’s easy to get caught up in the thoughts of what might happen or how things could have been, but this only keeps you from enjoying the here and now.  Instead, focus your attention on what’s going on around you right at this moment. Notice the colors, the sounds, the smells, and how your body feels. Appreciate the beauty of the world and savor every moment. The present is a gift, and you can make today great by living in it!  Perform a random act of kindness  Tip: Do something nice for someone  Kindness matters. Kindness makes a difference. Whether it’s writing a thank you note, giving a random stranger a compliment, helping a neighbor with chores, or donating to an organization in need, performing any act of kindness can be one of the most rewarding activities.  Doing something for others is a great way to show gratitude as well as to provide a boost of positive energy. When you help others, you not only make them feel good, but you also make yourself feel good. Whenever you’re feeling sad, lonely, or emotional, try practicing kindness.  Get enough sleep  Tip: Start a sleep journal to track what works and what doesn’t  Everyone has different definitions of what is enough sleep. Only you know your body and how many hours of sleep are needed for your physical and mental health. Numerous research studies have proven that a well-rested person is less sensitive to negative emotions and more responsive to positive feelings. If you’re not getting enough sleep, you’re more likely to feel stressed, anxious, and depressed. Take an afternoon nap, or go to bed a little earlier than usual. Your body (and your mind) will thank you.  Final thoughts  Tip: Choose happiness. You do happy. You be happy.  Happiness is an important part of living a healthy, fulfilling life. Start with one of these happiness hacks and see how it affects your mood. From there, you can add a few more until you find the perfect combination of happiness-boosting habits that work for you!

Tribune News Service  Ludhiana, May 23  A doctor reportedly ended his life by hanging himself at his clinic in Baba Colony here this afternoon.  The incident came to light when his family members reached the clinic in the afternoon and found the doctor’s body hanging from a rope.  When the information reached the police, officials of the Jodhewal police station reached the scene and shifted the body to the Civil Hospital for a post-mortem examination.  The deceased has been identified as Sandeep Kumar (32), a resident of the Meharban locality.  The victim owned a clinic, Verma Clinic. The family members stated that Sandeep had left home in the morning and went to his clinic. When they called him during lunchtime, he did not answer the phone. Subsequently, one of his family members went to the clinic to enquire about his lunch but found its shutter closed. When the shutter was opened, the victim’s body was found hanging from a rope.  However, no suicide note was recovered from the clinic.  The police said a probe was launched in the case.

LUTTRELL, Tenn. (WATE) — A months-long investigation has determined a Union County man shot four children and set his house on fire before committing suicide, the district attorney wrote Monday.  Eighth Judicial District Attorney General Jared Effler filed a memorandum on Monday following an investigation into a January 29 house fire in Luttrell. He made the determination that Charles Aljumaily shot four children and killed himself based on evidence found by Tennessee Bureau of Investigation special agents.  Briseis Aljumaily, 15, Audrie Cooper-Fortner, 9, Gabriella Aljumaily, 5, and Evie Cooper-Fortner, 5, were found dead in the home.  Effler wrote that autopsies and ballistic evidence indicate that all four children were shot before the house caught fire. Charles Aljumaily, the father of Briseis Aljumaily and Gabriella Aljumaily and grandfather to Audrie and Evie Cooper-Fortner, is believed to have shot all four before setting the house fire and shooting himself.  Autopsies determined that all four were killed by gunshots from a .45 caliber Sig Sauer handgun, which was found near Charles Aljumaily. He died from a single gunshot to the head. The gun was purchased by Aljumaily in 2013 and registered to him.  Special agents found that the deadbolt on the home’s front door remained in a locked position after it had been breached by firefighters.  TBI special agents interviewed multiple family members. One told an investigator that Aljumaily was diagnosed with borderline bipolar disorder. They reported he had been paranoid recently and told them for the last few months that there was “a devil in his head attacking him.” He also reportedly said he wanted to harm himself but was afraid to because of how that would affect his salvation.  A relative also told a TBI agent that they suspected Aljumaily of being bipolar and that he was on medication, but stopped taking it because he did not like how it made him feel.  Another relative told investigators that Aljumaily said a few months prior that he “felt like ending it.” Minutes before the fire was reported, Aljumaily told a relative by phone that “it’s bad right now, it’s not good right now.”  Effler wrote that no criminal charges will be brought because Charles Aljumaily is dead.  “In my twenty-three(23) years as a prosecutor, this is one of the most tragic and heartbreaking cases I have ever encountered,” wrote Effler about the case.

AUGUSTA, Ga. (WJBF)– May is Mental Health Awareness Month, and one man in Utah is shining a light on men’s mental health. Sarah Murphy met the man behind the I Love You, Bro project.  “I actually was thinking, I cannot let this happen. My kids are gonna watch this happen. They’re never gonna forget this,” Joe Tuia’ana remembers.  What started as a regular drive home for Joe Tuia’ana, became a life-changing experience. In January, 2022, Joe and his daughters saw a man standing on a freeway overpass, about to jump off into oncoming traffic. Joe immediately got out of the car.  “I was overwhelmed with fear, and I said a quick little prayer. The only thing that I could think of to say was, ‘I love you, bro.’ And I grabbed him by the hoodie and the belt and we slid down this concrete embankment and just sat on the sidewalk, and I just kind of held him like he was one of my kids.”  It was a life-changing moment led to a friendship, and those four words stuck with him. He created the I Love You, Bro project, which is a platform focused on talking about men’s mental health.  The project helps men get connected with mental health professionals.  The suicide rate for men in the United States is four times higher than it is for women. LGBTQ men, soldiers and first responders are more vulnerable to suicide.  In 2021, more than 47,000 people in the US died by suicide. 38,025 of those were men. You can find lots of information and ways to help people in crisis on the projects website, iloveyoubro.net.  And never forget, the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline provides free and confidential support for people in distress 24 hours a day, seven days a week. Just dial 988.
